ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of the Chinese language

Greater writing/essay () skills and knowledge in the Chinese language, better vocabulary and speaking skills but more specifically discussing more mature topics like housing, China's  (hukou system) and others.
learned how to discuss more formal topics in Chinese, explored contemporary social issues in China and learned about Chinese history/culture
I improved my chinese reading and writing abilities and learned a lot about the culture through the pieces read.
I learned more about Chinese culture and society, as well as many new phrases and idioms. This class also challenged my reading comprehension, speech and writing.
I really deepened my appreciation for Chinese culture and learned a lot more about the sociopolitical problems in China.
Expanded my Chinese vocabulary and improved my grammar significantly
Lots of vocabulary surrounding the issues China has faced from the 1950s till now.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Professor super passionate about teaching and is often lenient for his students who may have midterms or other extracurricular activities at the same time as a presentation or essay date. 
Weaknesses: Wish we could be speaking more or discussing more in class, but that's what the Chinese tables are usually for.
This course over zoom faced some limitations (namely, less opportunity to converse in Chinese in a group setting). Strengths: Su laoshi is the best, and you meet so many great people in the class.
I wished the professor would flesh out more of the sentence structures and the phrases. Sometimes, it was difficult to follow along because of how advanced and/or tangential the material could get.

Strengths: Very interesting, especially because of Su Lao Shi and his teaching style. 
Weaknesses: Essays were at times a bit tedious, but ultimately I enjoyed writing them.
Professor was great and very engaging which made the course great all around

Strengths: If you want to fully work in China in the future, it's likely this course will be a necessary base to actually be able to communicateit provides cultural background and vocabulary.

Weaknesses: There's so much content covered in such a short time that oftentimes things are lost. Also, learning traditional characters for some of these complex vocab words seems a little worthless.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think this class adapted pretty well, and many students may actually prefer taking it online because they don't have to write as much and can practice their pinyin or typing Chinese skills.
I think this course was adapted pretty well for online learning. All functions of the course were carried out well.
Su Laoshi was often lenient with assignments and very accommodating.
The course seemed to go smoothly even in Covid times
N/A; there really wasn't any adaptation towards COVID-19 learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I learned a lot throughout the course, and Su Laoshi is great.
YES! Great class to learn Chinese in a less stressful format and develop good friendships with classmates!
Absolutley.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Su laoshi is an amazing teacher and my Chinese improved drastically.
Yes, if you wanted to complete the Chinese language sequence at Yale. Su Wei is an interesting professor with a lot to say and teach.

YES! Please take a class with Su Laoshi, you will learn so much about China & Chinese culture (through both the text and all his fun anecdotes) and walk away with such a deep appreciation for the beauty of the Chinese language.
Yes, great professor and great material to learn. Definitely can be difficult and likely would have been even more difficult in-person but very much worth taking
Yes, only if they want to work in China/Taiwan in the future. Otherwise, the vocab and content is too specialized to really be useful in day-to-day conversation.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were no other modes of learning.
N/A
N/A
All were live lectures
